comments.commentBody: I have long felt that if the recession had begun in 2004 instead of 2007, we would be looking at solid Democratic majorities in both houses and two presidential landslides with a third on the way.  Only because of the short interval between the market collapse and the inauguration were conservatives able to falsely try to pin the economy on Obama.  Of course having Bush run the economy for an additional three years as Hoover did probably would have led to a full depression.

And after a generally smart 5 years of New Deal governing, Congress almost killed the FDR administration's best-laid plans when it turned back to Hooverian austerity. Unemployment soared and GDP languished again. Mark Thomason and Paul Krugman have learned history's economic lessons, but Europe wants to shut its eyes and pockets, as though it were the Papa with a a misbehaving child. Look in the mirror: as Pgo said, "We has met the enemy and he is us.". Now fix yourself, EU, and mend your ways. Mark and Paul know the gospel of economic good news.

IMO, your comments are worth repeating, often.  It seems to me that an overwhelming majority of respondents here, and my acquaintances in general, deny that the primary factor behind the debt problems of the U.S. and Greece and Brazil and ... The list goes on and on... Is that the tax and financial policies overwhelmingly favor the rich and economic elite.  Most important, the point that they deny is this: what they call irresponsiibility on the part of the wealthy and the government of other countries has been codified into law here -- laws written in direct response to the massive monetary corruption.  I'm speaking here of the wealthy - rich & corporations ( primarily bankers, but Koch bros. types also) to buy politicians and order them to write these despicable  'laws'.  Democracy of, by, and for the people, no.  Taxation without representation, yes.

Greece is a prime example of what austerity does to an economy. There, but for the grace of god and the voters who kept the GOP out of the White House in 2008 and 2012, could have gone the United States.

It's funny how when a nation's budget needs fixing, it's always the common people rather than the elite that bear the burden. In Greece's case, the mess was caused by widespread tax evasion at the top, while in the US it's tax avoidance, legalized by legislation written on behalf of the avoiders. Same thing, different names. Greece and the US also have in common bloated military spending. The most useful thing Greece could do for itself is sit down with Turkey so that the two nations can work out how to free themselves from the chains of their past history and scale back their militaries accordingly.

This is one best things i'v ever heard of. The Hobo Pack is both easy and convenient, for families who enjoy a hearty meal instead of hot dogs and marshmallows. I come from a family who enjoys going camping, but we bring basic things such as various types of lunch meat, bread, and other condiments. The Hobo Pack would be the ideal dinner for us instead of the regular camping treats, because it is basically like eating a roast.
Camper Specials is what my husband calls that meal. Delicious under the stars.

Definitely a Scouts memory.  We made bulls-eyes: glazed doughnuts with a marshmallow in the middle and M&Ms all around.  After grilling burgers, the foil-wrapped bulls-eyes were toasted at the park on the free grills.  Outstanding!  And to those critical of the hobo packet stew ingredients - don't knock it till you try it.  Kids love ketchup and basic food!

Well, I'm born and raised Cajun also. My family were crawfish farmers in Evangeline Parish. I've been to literally hundreds of crawfish boils in my life, and I have never been to a crawfish boil *without* potatoes. Not sure where you were attending boils (probably in Dallas).
Sometimes we've had garlic, sausage, artichokes, mushrooms onions, etc. Those ingredients come and go, but every boil I have been to had corn and potatoes. Just google image "crawfish boil" and take a look at the pictures.

In all seriousness, every boil has its own style, even the poor potato-less texas boils!

Fresh corn only takes a few minutes, and those sausages were clearly pre-cooked (probably by smoking) before going in. They are getting warmed up and picking up additional seasoning, not being cooked.

Such snobbery. Of course fresh corn is best, but maybe sometimes it's easier for someone to utilize what is easier for them to get. And  the Hillshire sausage dis. What a  snob. Would love to see your shopping cart bill. Apparently money is no object. Not everyone has an unlimited income for food shopping, even people that read the NY Times!

I like the idea of toasting the bread and "chad" in the toaster first.  Have been eating these  "eggs in a frame"  since my days in Girl Scouts. And yes, we did cook them over a tuna can stove.  I still make them, only now it's with my homemade whole wheat bread in a cast iron skillet.
This recipe represents one of the things I most love about Martha Rose Shulman: She embraces and celebrates the simple in culinary arts.

I am very much looking forward to exploring Cava with guidance.  Owing to my Italian heritage, I have always savored Prosecco, and when I was younger, Asti Spumanti, which some scorn, but whatever-I agree with José that good wine is what you like.  I am in no danger of comparisons to Champagne, as I have no meaningful experience with it that would allow me to make those comparisons-which I think is also too bad, but maybe one day I will explore Champagne.  Cava is very popular in my husband's birthplace of Puerto Rico and we drink it when we are there, nearly every time we go visiting.  I like what I have had, but not knowing what to look for in the wine, if I do anything I should not, I compare it to Prosecco!  I will stop that now and explore….salute!
We were in NY a few weeks ago and ate at Anito Lo's restaurant Annisa. She certainly knows how to cook bluefish - I had her bluefish with grapeleaves - best bluefish dish I've ever had.

Being Boston-born, my husband and I have always loved bluefish. The last time we had it was in 2009 in Boston at a restaurant called 'Skipjack's' (which, unfortunately is no longer in business). Bluefish, among many other delicacies on your site, are not available in SW Florida, so all I can do is sigh. We lived in Michigan before retiring to Marco, and it was occasionally available at local markets. Usually, I just doused the fillets with plenty of lemon juice, salt and pepper and topped it with fresh bread crumbs and dots of butter. Then, into the broiler it went until done (Don't ask me how long; I can't remember.). I always found it to be similar to but more flavorful than mackerel, another fish not available here. Sailor friends of ours used to trawl for King Mackerel. It is silver, not dark blue and stripped. It's also not as flavorful, but we don't look a gift horse in the mouth.

Glad to see its appearance on this site. We thought they'd been fished out.

Exactly. I go with a 'little of this and a bit of that' of whatever catches my eye from the spice shelf. Always a tablespoon of ketchup though. It seems to meld the flavors together. Then simmer in a crock, cool a bit, and simmer.
Thank you NY Times for this wonderfully simple recipe. The beans were creamy, flavorful, and ... heavenly! I let mine slow cook for almost three hours and used a full pound of slab bacon.

In case you did not know, Tex-Mex is not "true" Mexican.  It is the food of  Tejanos (Texans of Mexican descent).  It is the fusion of traditional northern Mexican with mission-era Spanish and the cuisines of other immigrant groups.  It is a distinct and separate cuisine from "true" Mexican.
Ligaya, you use the most evocative language in your food writing!
Congratulations David Tanis!  What a marvelous recipe!  We followed the recipe exactly except for adding a couple of tbls. of cream to the ricotta.  Loved it and it also reheated well the leftovers!

Beef that is chopped in a blender, rather than ground beef, makes a superior burger.
Also barbecued beef, pork or chicken that is chopped in a blender, rather than pulled, makes a superior barbecue dish.

And that will require debt relief and either reform of the Eurozone and EU or perhaps the destruction of Eurozone or of both the EU and Eurozone. So a win for Europe is uncertain and a long way off. And though Greece has chosen the only economically rational course in rejecting the proffered program of austerity, its future will be difficult, dangerous, and uncertain, even though it has made the only choice that offers a future.

P.S. As I am sure our esteemed teacher has realized, by adjusting the debt to GDP ratio and the primary budget balance as variables to reflect any debt ratio and any primary balance as a certain amount of either deficit or surplus or zero, his analysis can be applied to any nation in a common currency area to show the economic effects on growth and inflation of any set of debt ratios and primary budget balances. Of course, inflation could also be a variable, as the central bank could increase the money supply to increase inflation, at least when the currency area's economy is not at zero lower bound.

I made a mistake when I wrote, supra: "Of course, inflation could also be a variable, as the central bank could increase the money supply to increase inflation, at least when the currency area's economy is not at zero lower bound." That is not correct. I should have written: "Of course, inflation could also be a variable, as the central bank could increase the money supply to increase inflation in a member state, at least when that state's economy is not at zero lower bound (ZLB)."

And, even then what makes this effective policy for correcting trade imbalances inside a currency area is that the rates of inflation in the different member states will be different, with those states not at ZLB e and which are closer to full employment having, ceteris paribus, a higher rate of inflation than states which are farther from full employment. The exports of the states with lower rates of inflation will be more competitive, and that will be a force and perhaps a sufficient force for correcting trade imbalances.

Certainly, democracy in Greece, which is democracy's birthplace, has won today, but whether Europe has won or even Greece has won remains to be seen.

In “Austerity Arithmetic,” Prof. Krugman gives a conclusive analysis and method of calculating whether, given a nation's ration of debt to GDP or GNP, as the case may be, it is possible, given a certain level of primary surplus, for a nation payoff its debts, or, if it can pay its debts how long it must labor under austerity to do so. So economics gives a definitive analysis for whether austerity of certain primary surplus can be paid and, if so, at what costs.

So much for the economics. It tells the parties to a negotiation on a nation's debt what the debtor's bottom line position is, that is, when it is better to leave a currency area and institute its own currency, rather than undertake austerity.

But Krugman realizes, of course, the implications of his analysis, supra. Any nation can apply that analysis to determine whether a program of austerity is viable and, if so, the time and costs involved. And so it is not just Greece but Ireland, Italy, Spain, Portugal, or any nation that accepted a bailout program which can apply Krugman's textbook analysis to evaluate its austerity program and determine whether the euro is worth it.

And they shall, with the result that the Eurozone will face calls, which have already begun, to renegotiate their respective austerity programs. (cont.)

What you are describing is an agrarian Puerto Rico that is no more. That was the reality in the 1920s. The real economy is based on tax advantages to USA companies and federal programs. It was a showcase for the USA during the Cold War. But now it served its propaganda role and its strategic military position as the Cold War is no more. Now is Cuba and the 3.5 million USA citizens in the island are a mere footnote for most mainland politicians. Puertorricans need to realize the current status is powerless to fix this problem. They need to go for statehood or independence. Or move the whole population to the mainland were they are magically transformed into full USA citizens with all their rights.

I have no idea why property taxes are so low on the island but I would sure like to know.

JLfc do you have an opinion on this issue?

Not mentioned in this article is that politics in Puerto Rico is controlled by a very wealthy consortium of land owners who for generations dictate the economics for the Island, particularly the tax structure  and more particularly property taxes. This cabal of wealthy land owners have maintained a low tax on land holdings allowing unused, former sugar plantations to remain unproductive and out of the reach of alternative uses, keeping the price of land out of reach for the poor and entrepreneurs.  This low or no tax on property has prevented the poor, and made it difficult for the middle class to obtain at a reasonable price for  a home or productive farm or small industry. It has also blocked infrastructure growth since there are no incentives to build in areas not economically viable.

What could happen, however is a US government bailout for the Island conditioned to real property tax reform where the wealthy corporations and families holding the properties are required to pay taxes on their land holdings at a rate similar to other places, such as the central valley in California where such processes encourage use of the land for the best economic production and opportunities for employment and generate economic growth and stability.
